properties.media:imagetext:
- 3 -
The Escolta is a row of dirty wooden shacks for the most part with
thousands upon
thousands of Filipinos milling around in a maze o.?
jeeps,
carametas,
trucks, motor cars and taxis.
The din, dirt and
confusion is
beyond description.
In short,
the Far East has changed and will never again
return to
the life out here as we once knew it.
Returning to
Hongkong Saturday
morning,
there was no PAA schedule
for several days so I
came over with Philippine Airways in a very
fine DC-4.
Three other airplanes left that same norning all DC-3 type ships (not so good
for crossing
many miles of ocean) for China and I remembered that 16 years
ago we
made
first
round trip from China to the Philippines !
Returning here
I found a cable relayed from New York to
"phone
George
Sellett.
The
Iphone company said they would put me on the witing
list and
perhaps within four or five days I might get through.
However, Alli knew the
President and asked him for help.
In a half hour I had George on the "phone
but a
very
poor circult.
He had planned to ask me to come out from New York
and was
of course very
pleased to know that I was already here.
I called
again the next day and got a much better connection.
He said the "Liberation"
authorities were anxious to see us and were very glad that we were here.
He
thought that we would be permitted to resume Pan American service within e
few days or maybe a week.
That was the 5th of June and todey on
the 10th we
have received no
further
word.
We had lunch with Lewis Clark yesterday and he advised us very
strongly to go over
to Macao - intimating that Macao might become a very in-
portat
point.
You can
draw your own
conclusions! Bondy and I plan to go
over
there
Sunday
the 12th and spend a few days.
will probably try to get
the Government to
complete an air strip which is already partially con-
structed.
Will call on Gellion and our other friends over there.
Of course
if a green light is
received fron Shanghai will come right back.
My views
regarding the whole Chinese situation have
changed
since
arriving here and
talking to American, British and Chinese officials.
I had
hoped that it might be possible
for
the Nationalists to get together
and hold
"beach-head" somewhere in South China.
Of course anything can happen as
evidenced by
the man who
now sits in the White House.
But the situation
appears absolutely hopeless.
Chiang Kai-shek will not let go.
He is still
playing one
political leader against another so
that none will
emerge to
challenge his position.
General L:
the seting President and
General Pal
were the former strong men of Kwangsi,
the model Province.
The Generalissimo
is afraid
that they may agein gain complete control of Kwangsi
and
break away
from the so-celled
"Central Goverament",
so he has ordered General
Pal
to make
a stend with his Kwangsi troops at lleng Tang south of Changsha on the Hankow-
Canton Esilroad.
Chiang hopes -
they say - that General
Pai and his troops
will be taken by
the Conmunists and
thus unable to retreat to Kwangsi.
At
least that is
the opinion of some usually well-informed
people.
You remember
the old proverb - "Brothers stop quarrelling when
there's a tiger at the door."
Well,
the
Nationalists are not following that idea and the concensus of
opinion is that
the Communists will
take
Canton just as soon as their troops
have time
to walk that far.
There may be a few provinces which will hold out
for months or maybe years against the
Communists but they
are in the west and
northwest
beyond
the reach of rail or river traffic and of little importance
to
trade.
